immediately.translation[0].definitions[0: Mix in the remaining ingredients and serve immediately.
The telephone rang, and he answered it immediately.
In everyday English, people usually say right away or, in British English, straight away rather than immediately:
Yes, I’ll do it right away.
immediately.translation[0].definitions[1: very soon before or after something
He retired immediately after the end of the war.
I can’t remember what happened immediately before the crash.
immediately.translation[0].definitions[2: the seat immediately behind the driver
immediately behind/above/below/in front of etc something
immediately.translation[0].note_box[0].s: very soon after something else happens, and without any delay
Sam immediately offered to help.
at once
immediately – used especially for emphasis
Remove the pie from the oven and serve at once.
He came home at once when he heard his wife was ill.
right away
immediately, especially because something is urgent. Right away and straightaway are less formal than immediately, and are very common in everyday spoken English
If this happens, let us know right away.
I apologized straightaway.
instantly
if something happens instantly, it happens immediately after something else, with almost no time between
The boy was killed instantly.
The message is sent instantly from your computer.
right now/this minute
if someone orders you to do something right now, they want you to do it immediately, especially because they are annoyed with you
The head teacher wants to see you right now.
without delay
immediately, because it is important that you do something as soon as possible
If you lose your passport, you should contact the embassy without delay.
immediately.translation[1].definitions[0: Immediately you begin to speak, he gives you his full attention.
